Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Advanced Processing and Materials Characterization
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY: This is a 10-week summer program whose main objective is to provide a research and education experience to 10 undergraduate students in the broad area of Materials Science and Engineering at the University of North Texas. This program will involve faculty in three different departments, Materials Science and Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, and Physics, with an emphasis on training undergraduate students in designing, fabricating, and testing a wide variety of materials. These activities have the potential to influence these students by providing them with real-life experience conducting research in materials science and engineering. Each summer, the Site will recruit 10 undergraduate students to be part of this mentoring program provided by a diverse group of faculty members. The focus will be on providing research opportunities for minorities, women, underrepresented groups, and students from non-PhD granting and/or non-research intensive institutions. During the course of this program, the students will develop skills characteristic of scientific researchers in literature review, materials design, hands-on laboratory skills, problem solving, experiment planning and design, and writing and presenting technical papers. The program will also provide students with relevant information regarding graduate school. This will include helping students to identify suitable programs, to understand the available financial resources, to complete the application process, and to recognize the job prospects after completion of a graduate program.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY: The specific materials design, preparation, and characterization techniques that the students will learn include coating processes, arc melting, wire drawing, rod and plate rolling, sintering, X-Ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy, focused ion beam techniques, Raman spectroscopy, Auger electron spectroscopy, wear testing, mechanical testing, density functional theory, and molecular dynamics. Major goals of this program include: (1) improviing students' communication skills through reports/papers, presentations, and posters and through working within the research team involved in their specific project, (2) performing research effectively under the supervision of a faculty mentor and from undergraduates, graduate students, post-doctoral researchers, and other research colleagues, (3) developing students' ability to ask scientific questions, (4) developing analytical and computational skills to answer scientific questions, (5) inspiring students to pursue careers in materials science and engineering and related STEM fields through a series of workshops, and (6) gaining familiarity with the role of each group member who is involved in a project to guide students' future performance in these roles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project represents a Research Experiences for Undergraduates site in Advanced Processing and Materials Characterization, which has operated successfully at the University of North Texas in the last three years.  Thirty students from 25 institutions from all across the United States have so far participated in this program. The program offers a 10-week summer program to provide a hands-on research and educational experience to 10 undergraduate students per year in the broad area of Materials Science and Engineering with an emphasis on Processing-Structure-Property relationship.  Specific tools that the students learned include processing techniques (e.g. chemical and physical vapor deposition, arc melting, rod and plate rolling, sintering) and characterization (e.g. X-Ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy, focused ion beam, Raman spectroscopy, Auger electron spectroscopy). The proposed model included: (1) Improving students communication skills through technical reports/papers, presentations, and posters, (2) Performing research effectively through mentorship from a faculty mentor as well graduate students, and post-doctoral researchers, (3) Developing the ability to ask scientific questions, (4) Developing analytical/computational skills to answer scientific questions, (5) Inspiring students to careers in materials science and engineering and related STEM fields through bi-weekly workshops that include creating solar cells, producing jewelry, the art of publishing, and how to apply for graduate school, (6) Gaining familiarity with the roles of each group member involved in student projects to improve her/his future accessibility in these roles. 

Intellectual Merit: Our UNT team hosted a total of 30 students in that time (10 each per summer). The REU students worked continuously from the beginning of the REU program until the end to produce or simulate materials, characterize their physical and chemical properties, and test their performance. Throughout their individual projects, REU students created preliminary drafts of research documents such as reports/papers and presentations.  At the end of the 10-week mentoring period, each REU student submitted a final report and gave a 15-minute presentation on their project.  After the program ended, 28/30 (93.33%) had stated that they are very or somewhat likely to attend graduate school once they graduate with a bachelor’s degree. This award resulted in a total of 12 publications (accepted, in press, and submitted), and a total of 26 conference presentations at local, national, and international conferences.

Broader Impact: In addition to scientific activities, the students participated in many social activities to help develop personal relationships with faculty and other researchers and to strengthen their sense of belonging within a scientific community. In addition to attending the seminar from faculty on research and the roles of researchers, the REU students were engaged in the following workshops/field trips: 

  • The Art of Publishing: The students attended a seminar on the art of publishing, which included diverse topics such as the art of writing scientific papers, plagiarism and self-plagiarism, the important criteria to satisfy the novelty requirement of scientific articles, a global view/trends on scientific research and publishing, etc.
  • Green Technology: The participants attended a workshop on Green technology, which included hands-on experiments in the fabrication, characterization, and testing of dye-sensitized solar cells.
  • Jewelry Making: The students attended a Jewelry making workshop, which included soldering, brazing, joining, wire drawing, plate rolling, and hot- and cold-working.  The figure below shows students creating earrings from raw materials. 
  • Field trips:  The REU students had the opportunity to participate in field trips to the Dallas Museum of Art, the Perot Museum of Nature and Science, and to Raytheon or Halliburton.
